Custom is here ol no value against Divine law; il money is given for the consecration os a bishop, sorau abbot’s instalment‚ dre, it is simony. If only at such ceremonies, as a customary see, it is not indeed simony; but great care sould be taken to avoid the very appearance ol simony or ol greed in such casce. A candidate sor a bishopric has not the right to appease an unjust opponent either by money or by a promise ol money, when he has become a Bishop, however, he may without sin take steps to get rid os persecution. Money may be given lor the sustenance of the clergy, hut there must be no intention either to buy or to sell spiritual services; and is money be withheld, the priest must take care to render his ser· vices as before. No one is allowed to receive anything (except as a free gift) on the occasion ol admission into a monastery. lt is forbidden to sell the consecrated vessels, so long as they retain their lorm; in cases ol necessity, they must first be broken. A Bishop may, without simony and for pious uses, take certain lirst-fruits from a benefice before it is conferred; but to order the beneficiary to give the first-fruita would be simony. Simoniacs should be deprived ol their livings; priests whose ordination is infected with simony receive the sacerdotal powerS, but not the right nor the grace to exercise them. lt is not allowed to receive Holy Orders from a bishop promoted by simony, even il this is only known certainly, without any legal prool. This short summary of the more important points in the question De Simonia may be suflicient to show that the Church, in principle at least, and concerning simony in the contracted meaning given to it, is hardly less severe than Wyclif.
